awd_titl_txt: Precise Q Values for Ultra-Low Energy and Highly Forbidden Beta Decays Using Penning Trap Mass Spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The study of extreme phenomena in the physical sciences has often provided new discoveries and insights. In this project the PI will investigate one extreme limit of radioactive decays: beta-decays that occur with very low energy. These decays are interesting because they can be used in experiments to determine the mass of the neutrino (the light, neutral particle that is also emitted in beta-decay) and because they require the development of a more detailed theoretical description of the effect of atomic electrons on the nuclear decay process. To date, only one ultra-low energy beta decay has been observed (that of Indium-115). There are many other potential candidates, but the atomic masses of the parent and daughter nuclei are not known precisely enough to determine whether the proposed decay can actually occur. In this project the PI will perform precision atomic mass measurements of low energy beta decay systems using Penning trap mass spectrometry. The technique involves confining ions with magnetic and electric fields and then measuring the ion cyclotron frequency in the trap; from which atomic mass can be determined. Experiments will take place at Michigan State University and at Central Michigan University (CMU), providing training in experimental nuclear physics techniques for undergraduate and Ph.D. students at CMU.

Weak decay processes such as nuclear beta-decay have provided significant contributions to our understanding of nuclear, atomic and particle physics. They continue to be of interest to aid our understanding of astrophysical processes, nuclear structure, fundamental symmetries, and properties of the neutrino. Very rare weak decay processes, such as highly forbidden, ultra-low Q value, and double-beta decays are important for investigating the particle nature and mass scale of the neutrino, modelling and understanding the background in very low count rate experiments, and for testing theoretical descriptions of nuclear beta-decay. In the proposed work, the PI will perform precise measurements of Q values for potential ultra-low energy beta-decay systems using LEBIT at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB). The decays of interest occur between the ground state of the parent nuclide and an excited state in the daughter with an energy of <1 keV. The proposed measurements will help to identify isotopes that are potential candidates for ultra-low Q value decays. These isotopes could be used in future neutrino mass experiments and will also be important for enabling meaningful tests of nuclear theory for these extreme decays where atomic interference effects are expected to play a significant role. por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to shed new light on the existence of radioactive isotopes that could undergo a very low energy beta-decay transition, a so-called ultra-low Q-value beta-decay. These decays are of great interest because they have the potential to be used in experiments that aim to determine the mass of the neutrino, and because they can provide tests of atomic and nuclear theory as it is used to describe beta-decay.

In an ultra-low Q-value beta-decay, the transition would occur from the ground-state of the parent nucleus to an excited state in the daughter. The energy of the excited state level in the daughter, E*, must be very close to the total energy that would be released in beta-decay to the ground state of the daughter nucleus, Qgs, so that the difference Q* = Qgs - E* is small (see figure 1). In fact, Q* must be <1 keV for the transition to be considered ultra-low in energy.

A major outcome of this work was a study that we performed to identify isotopes that could potentially undergo an ultra-low Q-value decay. To do this we first determined Qgs values for all beta-decaying isotopes. These can be calculated from the mass of the parent and daughter atoms whose values are given in the literature, for example in the Atomic Mass Evaluation. We compared the Qgs values with E* values given in databases such as the National Nuclear Data Center to find cases with Q* values close to 1 keV. We found that ~100 potential candidates exist. However, the Q* value was typically not known precisely enough to determine whether Q* really is <1 keV (to make the decay ultra-low) and >0 keV (so that it is energetically allowed). In many cases this was due to the fact that the atomic masses of the parent and daughter atoms were not known precisely enough to make this determination.

One of the major goals of this project was to use Penning trap mass spectrometry to perform precise mass measurements on parent and/or daughter atoms for the potential ultra-low Q-value decays that we identified. A pair of candidates that we identified was 75Se and 75Ge that both decay to the stable daughter isotope, 75As. Each has a potential ultra-low Q-value decay to an excited state in 75As (see figure 2). However, the mass of 75As was not known precisely enough to determine whether these two decays really were ultra-low. 

An outcome of this project was an experiment that we performed using the LEBIT Penning trap at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) at MSU to measure the mass of 75As (see data in figure 3). The result of the experiment provided a precise and accurate new measurement of the mass of 75As and showed that 75Ge cannot undergo an ultra-low Q value decay, but that 75Se could have an ultra-low Q-value decay. This result has motivated to need for a new, more precise determination of E* for the nuclear state in 75As that 75Se would decay to. We plan to perform this measurement in the future.

A further outcome of this project was the development of experimental proposals to measure Qgs values for additional potential ultra-low Q-value decay candidates. This has involved continuing collaborations with the LEBIT Penning trap group at FRIB, and developing new collaborations with the CPT Penning trap group at Argonne National Lab (ANL), the ion trapping group at Notre Dame, and the JYFLTRAP Penning trap group in Jyvaskyla. As a result of this project, we have plans for approved experiments to take place at ANL and FRIB.
